canonical_explanation.text: The circulatory system transports blood throughout the body. Blood consists of plasma (liquid), red blood cells (RBCs - carry oxygen using hemoglobin), white blood cells (WBCs - fight infection), and platelets (blood clotting). The ABO blood group system has types A, B, AB, and O based on antigens. The Rh factor makes blood Rh positive or negative. The heart is a four-chambered muscular organ with two atria (upper) and two ventricles (lower). Valves prevent backflow. Blood vessels include arteries (carry blood away from heart, thick walls), veins (carry blood to heart, have valves), and capillaries (thin walls for exchange). Double circulation means blood passes through the heart twice in one complete circuit - pulmonary (heart-lungs-heart) and systemic (heart-body-heart). The lymphatic system helps immunity and fluid balance.
rules: Blood components: plasma, RBCs, WBCs, platelets
WBCs: fight infection, part of immune system
ABO blood groups: A, B, AB, O
Universal donor: O negative; Universal recipient: AB positive
Arteries: carry blood away from heart, thick walls
Veins: carry blood to heart, thin walls, have valves

questions.question_text: Which blood component carries oxygen?
questions.explanation_correct: Red blood cells (RBCs) carry oxygen throughout the body using a protein called hemoglobin. Hemoglobin binds to oxygen in the lungs and transports it to the body's cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: White blood cells (WBCs) help fight infections, platelets help with blood clotting, and plasma is the liquid part of blood. However, it is the red blood cells (RBCs) that are responsible for carrying oxygen using the hemoglobin protein.

questions.question_text: Platelets help in:
questions.explanation_correct: Platelets help in blood clotting. When a blood vessel is damaged, platelets rush to the site and stick together to form a clot. This prevents further blood loss and allows the wound to heal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Platelets do not carry oxygen, fight infection, or transport nutrients. Their main function is to help in blood clotting. When a blood vessel is damaged, platelets gather at the site, stick together, and form a clot to stop the bleeding.

questions.question_text: How many chambers does the human heart have?
questions.explanation_correct: The human heart has four chambers - two upper atria and two lower ventricles. This allows the heart to efficiently pump blood through the body's two main circulatory systems: the pulmonary circuit (heart-lungs-heart) and the systemic circuit (heart-body-heart).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The human heart does not have two, three, or five chambers. It has a total of four chambers - two upper atria and two lower ventricles. This four-chambered structure is essential for the heart to effectively pump blood through the body's two main circulatory systems: the pulmonary circuit and the systemic circuit.

questions.question_text: Blood vessels that carry blood away from the heart are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Arteries are the blood vessels that carry blood away from the heart to the rest of the body. They have thick, muscular walls that can pump blood efficiently to all the organs and tissues.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Veins carry blood back to the heart, while capillaries are the tiny blood vessels where the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products takes place. Lymph vessels are part of the lymphatic system, which is different from the circulatory system that transports blood.

questions.question_text: The universal blood donor type is:
questions.explanation_correct: The universal blood donor type is O negative because people with this blood type do not have any A or B antigens on their red blood cells, and they also lack the Rh factor. This means their blood can be safely given to people with any other blood type, including those with A, B, AB, or Rh positive or negative.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not the universal blood donor type because they have either A or B antigens, or they have the Rh factor present. People with A positive, B negative, or AB positive blood types cannot be universal donors as their blood may not be compatible with everyone else's blood types.

questions.question_text: Veins have valves to:
questions.explanation_correct: Veins have valves to prevent the backflow of blood. This is important because veins carry blood back to the heart, so the valves make sure the blood flows in the right direction and doesn't go back down.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Veins do not have valves to speed up blood flow, filter blood, or add oxygen. The valves in veins are there to prevent the backflow of blood. This is important because veins carry blood back to the heart, and the valves make sure the blood flows in the right direction and doesn't go back down.

questions.question_text: In double circulation, blood passes through the heart:
questions.explanation_correct: In double circulation, blood passes through the heart twice per complete circuit - once through the pulmonary circulation (heart-lungs-heart) and once through the systemic circulation (heart-body-heart).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is correct because in the human circulatory system, blood goes through the heart twice in one complete circuit. It first goes from the heart to the lungs (pulmonary circulation) and then back to the heart. Then it goes from the heart to the rest of the body (systemic circulation) and back to the heart again. So the blood passes through the heart a total of two times per full circuit.

questions.question_text: The protein in red blood cells that binds to oxygen is:
questions.explanation_correct: The protein in red blood cells that binds to oxygen is hemoglobin. Hemoglobin is a protein that carries oxygen from the lungs to the body's cells, making it essential for the circulatory system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is hemoglobin. Hemoglobin is a protein found in red blood cells that can bind to oxygen, allowing it to be transported throughout the body. The other options, such as fibrinogen, albumin, and globulin, are not the proteins that carry oxygen in red blood cells.

questions.question_text: Pulmonary circulation involves blood flow between:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B, because pulmonary circulation refers to the flow of blood between the heart and the lungs. This is one of the two main circuits of the human circulatory system, where blood travels from the heart to the lungs to pick up oxygen and then back to the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because they do not describe the path of pulmonary circulation. Option A refers to the systemic circulation, which is the flow of blood between the heart and the rest of the body. Option C is incorrect because the brain is not part of the pulmonary circuit. Option D is incorrect because the lungs and the body are not directly connected in the circulatory system - the lungs are part of the pulmonary circuit, while the body is part of the systemic circuit.

questions.question_text: The pacemaker of the heart is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The SA node, also called the sinoatrial node, is the pacemaker of the heart. It is located in the upper right atrium and generates electrical impulses that stimulate the heart to contract and pump blood through the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The AV node is not the pacemaker of the heart. It is located between the atria and ventricles and helps coordinate the contraction of the upper and lower chambers of the heart. The left ventricle and right atrium are also not the pacemakers of the heart. The SA node is the correct answer as it is the natural pacemaker that sets the rhythm of the heart.

questions.question_text: Arteries always carry oxygenated blood.
questions.explanation_correct: The statement is not entirely true. Arteries can carry both oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. The pulmonary arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs, while the systemic arteries carry oxygenated blood from the heart to the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The common misconception is that all arteries carry oxygenated blood. However, this is not the case. The pulmonary arteries, which carry blood from the heart to the lungs, actually carry deoxygenated blood. Only the systemic arteries, which carry blood from the heart to the rest of the body, transport oxygenated blood.

questions.question_text: The left ventricle has thicker walls than the right ventricle.
questions.explanation_correct: The left ventricle has thicker walls than the right ventricle because it needs to pump blood to the entire body, which requires more force. The right ventricle only needs to pump blood to the lungs, which is a shorter distance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The right ventricle does not have thicker walls than the left ventricle. The left ventricle is responsible for pumping blood to the entire body, which is a longer distance compared to the right ventricle, which only pumps blood to the lungs. This means the left ventricle needs to generate more force, which is why it has thicker walls.

questions.question_text: White blood cells are part of the immune system.
questions.explanation_correct: The statement 'White blood cells are part of the immune system' is true. White blood cells, also called leukocytes, are an important component of the immune system. They help fight infections and diseases by destroying harmful germs and bacteria.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement 'White blood cells are part of the immune system' is true. Some people may think white blood cells are not related to the immune system, but this is incorrect. White blood cells are essential for the body's defense against infections and illnesses. They are produced in the bone marrow and lymphatic system to protect the body from harmful microorganisms and other threats.

questions.question_text: A person with blood type AB can receive blood from any blood type.
questions.explanation_correct: A person with blood type AB can receive blood from any blood type because their blood has both A and B antigens. This means they can accept blood from people with types A, B, AB, and O.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. People with blood type AB can receive blood from any other blood type (A, B, AB, or O) because their blood has both A and B antigens. They do not produce antibodies against A or B antigens, so their body will accept blood from any donor.

questions.question_text: The liquid part of blood is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The liquid part of blood is called plasma. Plasma is the yellowish liquid part of blood that carries the red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets throughout the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is plasma. Blood is not made up of only cells - it also has a liquid component called plasma. Plasma is the fluid that carries the blood cells and other substances through the body. The other main components of blood are red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.

questions.question_text: The upper chambers of the heart are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The upper chambers of the heart are called atria (plural of atrium) because they receive blood flowing into the heart. The heart has two upper atria that collect blood from the body and the lungs, and then pump it down to the two lower ventricles which pump blood out to the body and the lungs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is atria. The heart has two upper chambers called atria, not ventricles. Ventricles are the two lower chambers of the heart that pump blood out to the lungs and the body. So the upper chambers are correctly referred to as atria.

questions.question_text: ___ are tiny blood vessels where gas and nutrient exchange occurs.
questions.explanation_correct: Capillaries are the tiny blood vessels where gas exchange (oxygen and carbon dioxide) and nutrient exchange occur between the blood and the body's tissues. This is because capillaries have very thin walls that allow substances to easily move in and out of the bloodstream.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'Capillaries'. Arteries, veins, and lymph vessels are not the correct answer because they do not directly facilitate gas and nutrient exchange. Capillaries have the thinnest walls among blood vessels, allowing materials to pass in and out of the bloodstream at the cellular level.

questions.question_text: In ___ circulation, blood flows from the heart to the body and back.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is 'systemic' because the systemic circulation refers to the flow of blood from the heart to the body and back to the heart again. This is one of the two main circulatory circuits in the human body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be 'pulmonary' because the pulmonary circulation is the flow of blood from the heart to the lungs and back to the heart. The systemic circulation, on the other hand, is the flow of blood from the heart to the rest of the body and back to the heart.

questions.question_text: Arrange the path of blood through the heart (starting from body):
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is: Right atrium receives blood, Lungs oxygenate blood, Left ventricle to body. This is because blood first enters the right atrium from the body, then goes to the lungs to get oxygenated, and finally enters the left ventricle to be pumped out to the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be: Left ventricle to body, Right atrium receives blood, Lungs oxygenate blood. This is wrong because the blood flow through the heart does not start from the left ventricle. The blood first enters the right atrium from the body, then goes to the lungs, and finally enters the left ventricle to be pumped out to the body.

questions.question_text: Arrange blood vessels by decreasing wall thickness:
questions.explanation_correct: Arteries have the thickest walls, followed by veins, and then capillaries have the thinnest walls. This is because arteries need thicker walls to withstand the high pressure of blood pumped out from the heart, while capillaries have very thin walls to allow for easy exchange of substances between blood and body tissues.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order from thickest to thinnest walls is: Arteries, Veins, Capillaries. Arteries have the thickest walls to withstand the high pressure of blood flow from the heart. Veins have thinner walls than arteries but thicker than the very thin-walled capillaries, which are designed for efficient exchange of substances between blood and body tissues.

questions.question_text: Which blood cells fight infection?
questions.explanation_correct: White blood cells (WBCs) are the cells in the blood that fight infection. They are part of the immune system and work to destroy germs and bacteria that can make you sick.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Red blood cells (RBCs) are the cells that carry oxygen in the blood, using a protein called hemoglobin. Platelets are the cells that help the blood to clot and stop bleeding. Plasma is the liquid part of the blood that carries the blood cells and other substances. The correct answer is white blood cells, which are the cells that fight infection in the body.

questions.question_text: The lower chambers of the heart are called:
questions.explanation_correct: The lower chambers of the heart are called ventricles. This is because the ventricles are the larger, lower chambers of the heart that pump blood out to the lungs and body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The lower chambers of the heart are not called atria, valves, or septa. Atria are the upper chambers of the heart that receive blood entering the heart. Valves are structures that control the flow of blood in the heart. Septa are the walls that separate the different chambers of the heart. The correct answer is that the lower chambers are called ventricles.

questions.question_text: The universal blood recipient is:
questions.explanation_correct: The universal blood recipient is AB positive because people with AB blood type have both A and B antigens on their red blood cells. This means they can receive blood from any blood type, making them the universal recipient.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The universal blood recipient is not O negative, O positive, or A positive. These blood types have specific antigens that limit the types of blood they can receive. Only AB positive blood type can receive blood from any other type, making them the universal recipient.

questions.question_text: Blood vessels that carry blood towards the heart are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Veins are the blood vessels that carry blood towards the heart. This is because veins have thinner walls and valves that help blood flow back to the heart, unlike arteries which carry blood away from the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Arteries carry blood away from the heart to the body's tissues. Capillaries are the tiny blood vessels where the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products takes place between the blood and body cells. Arterioles are the small arteries that branch off from the main arteries. So the correct option is veins, which carry blood towards the heart.

questions.question_text: Red blood cells are also called:
questions.explanation_correct: Red blood cells are also called erythrocytes because they contain the red pigment hemoglobin which helps them carry oxygen throughout the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Red blood cells are not the same as leucocytes (white blood cells), thrombocytes (platelets), or lymphocytes. Leucocytes fight infections, thrombocytes help in blood clotting, and lymphocytes are a type of white blood cell. The correct name for red blood cells is erythrocytes.

questions.question_text: The wall separating the left and right sides of the heart is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The wall separating the left and right sides of the heart is called the septum. This muscular wall divides the heart into two halves, ensuring that blood flows in the correct direction through the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is the septum. The septum is the wall that separates the left and right sides of the heart. It is not a valve, which is a structure that opens and closes to control the flow of blood. The pericardium is the outer protective sac around the heart, and the atrium is the upper chamber of the heart, not the wall separating the two sides.

questions.question_text: Why do arteries have thick walls?
questions.explanation_correct: Arteries have thick walls to withstand the high blood pressure as blood is pumped out of the heart. This helps the arteries maintain their shape and prevent rupture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Arteries do not have thick walls to prevent blood clotting, allow gas exchange, or store blood. The thick walls are specifically to withstand the high pressure of blood being pumped from the heart to the rest of the body. This keeps the arteries open and able to transport blood efficiently.

questions.question_text: The pulmonary artery carries:
questions.explanation_correct: The pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs, where it gets oxygenated. This is part of the pulmonary circulation, where blood travels from the heart to the lungs and back to the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pulmonary artery does not carry oxygenated blood to the body or the heart. Oxygenated blood is carried by the aorta, which is the main artery that sends oxygen-rich blood to the body. The pulmonary artery specifically transports deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs, where it gets re-oxygenated before returning to the heart.

questions.question_text: A person with low hemoglobin count would suffer from:
questions.explanation_correct: A person with low hemoglobin count would suffer from anemia. Hemoglobin is the protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen, so low levels mean the blood cannot transport enough oxygen to the body's tissues, leading to anemia.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not related to low hemoglobin count. Diabetes is high blood sugar, hypertension is high blood pressure, and goitre is an enlarged thyroid gland. Only anemia, which is low red blood cell count or low hemoglobin, is the correct answer here.

questions.question_text: The valve between the left atrium and left ventricle is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The valve between the left atrium and left ventricle is the bicuspid (or mitral) valve. This valve ensures blood flows in the right direction from the left atrium to the left ventricle, and prevents backflow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The tricuspid valve is between the right atrium and right ventricle. The aortic valve is between the left ventricle and the aorta, while the pulmonary valve is between the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery. The bicuspid (or mitral) valve is the correct answer as it is the valve that allows blood to flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle.

questions.question_text: The Rh factor refers to:

options.text: A type of white blood cell
A protein antigen on red blood cells

questions.explanation_correct: The Rh factor refers to a protein antigen on the surface of red blood cells. This antigen can be either present (+) or absent (-) in a person's blood, which determines their Rh blood type.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Rh factor is not a type of white blood cell, which are the cells that fight infection in the body. It also does not refer to a blood clotting factor or a type of plasma protein. The Rh factor is a protein found on the surface of red blood cells, and it determines whether a person's blood is Rh positive or Rh negative.

questions.question_text: Capillary walls are thin to allow:

options.text: White blood cells to be filtered

questions.explanation_correct: Capillary walls are thin to allow exchange of gases like oxygen and nutrients between the blood and body tissues. This allows essential substances to be delivered to cells and waste products to be removed from cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Capillaries have very thin walls to enable the exchange of substances between the blood and body tissues. This is important for the delivery of oxygen, nutrients, and other important molecules to cells. Blood clotting and the filtering of white blood cells happen in other parts of the circulatory system, not specifically in the capillaries.

questions.question_text: The pulmonary veins carry:
questions.explanation_correct: The pulmonary veins carry oxygenated blood from the lungs back to the heart. This is because the pulmonary circulation involves blood flowing from the heart to the lungs to pick up oxygen, and then returning the oxygenated blood to the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pulmonary veins do not carry deoxygenated blood to the heart or to the lungs. Deoxygenated blood from the body enters the right atrium of the heart, and then flows to the lungs through the pulmonary arteries. The pulmonary veins return the oxygenated blood from the lungs to the left atrium of the heart.

questions.question_text: Why is the left ventricle wall thicker than the right?

options.text: It pumps blood to the entire body
It is closer to the lungs

questions.explanation_correct: The left ventricle wall is thicker because it pumps blood to the entire body, which requires more force compared to the right ventricle which only pumps blood to the lungs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The left ventricle does not receive more blood, have more valves, or is closer to the lungs compared to the right ventricle. The right ventricle pumps blood to the lungs, while the left ventricle pumps blood to the entire body, which is why its wall is thicker to generate more force.

questions.question_text: Platelets are also called:
questions.explanation_correct: Platelets, also called thrombocytes, are responsible for blood clotting. They help stop bleeding by forming clots at the site of an injury or cut.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Platelets are not the same as erythrocytes (red blood cells), leucocytes (white blood cells), or lymphocytes. Erythrocytes carry oxygen, leucocytes fight infections, and lymphocytes are a type of white blood cell. Platelets are the blood cells that help with blood clotting and preventing excessive bleeding.

questions.question_text: The largest artery in the body is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The aorta is the largest artery in the body. It carries oxygen-rich blood from the left ventricle of the heart to the rest of the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pulmonary artery is not the largest artery in the body. It carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle of the heart to the lungs. The vena cava is a large vein that carries deoxygenated blood back to the heart, not an artery. The carotid artery is a major artery in the neck, but it is not the largest artery in the body.

questions.question_text: How many blood groups are there in the ABO system?
questions.explanation_correct: The ABO blood group system has four main blood groups: A, B, AB, and O. This is because there are two antigens (A and B) that can be present or absent on the surface of red blood cells, leading to these four possible combinations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The ABO blood group system does not have two, three, or six blood groups. There are four main blood groups based on the presence or absence of A and B antigens on red blood cells: A, B, AB, and O. The correct answer is four blood groups in the ABO system.

questions.question_text: Which blood component is responsible for transporting carbon dioxide?
questions.explanation_correct: Both plasma and red blood cells (RBCs) are responsible for transporting carbon dioxide. Plasma contains dissolved carbon dioxide, while RBCs carry most of the carbon dioxide through the body using a special protein called hemoglobin.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is C, both plasma and RBCs. RBCs, not platelets, are the main transporters of carbon dioxide in the body. Plasma also contains dissolved carbon dioxide, so both plasma and RBCs play a role in carbon dioxide transport throughout the circulatory system.

questions.question_text: The heart sound 'lub' is produced when:
questions.explanation_correct: The heart sound 'lub' is produced when the atrio-ventricular valves (tricuspid and mitral valves) close, preventing blood from flowing back into the atria from the ventricles. This is the first heart sound that occurs as the ventricles contract and pump blood out of the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The heart sound 'lub' is not produced when the semi-lunar valves (aortic and pulmonary valves) close, as this is the second heart sound. It also does not occur when blood enters the atria or leaves the heart, as these events do not produce an audible 'lub' sound. The 'lub' sound is specifically caused by the closing of the atrio-ventricular valves during ventricular contraction.

questions.question_text: Which blood vessel has the thinnest wall?
questions.explanation_correct: Capillaries have the thinnest walls of the blood vessels because they are responsible for the exchange of materials like oxygen, nutrients, and waste between the blood and the body tissues. This thin wall allows for efficient exchange.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Arteries, veins, and the aorta all have thicker walls compared to capillaries. Arteries have thick, muscular walls to withstand the high pressure of blood pumped from the heart. Veins have thinner walls than arteries, but thicker than capillaries, as they need to withstand less pressure. The aorta is the largest artery and has very thick, elastic walls to handle the high pressure of blood flow from the heart. Capillaries have the thinnest walls to allow for the easy exchange of substances between the blood and body tissues.

questions.question_text: Red blood cells have a nucleus.
questions.explanation_correct: Red blood cells (RBCs) do not have a nucleus. They are specialized cells that carry oxygen throughout the body using hemoglobin. Losing the nucleus allows RBCs to have a flexible, disc-like shape that can easily squeeze through narrow blood vessels.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Many students may think that red blood cells have a nucleus, but this is not correct. Red blood cells are designed to transport oxygen efficiently, so they do not have a nucleus. The lack of a nucleus allows RBCs to have a flexible, disc-like shape that helps them move through small blood vessels easily.

questions.question_text: The pulmonary vein carries oxygenated blood.
questions.explanation_correct: The pulmonary vein carries oxygenated blood from the lungs back to the heart. This is because the pulmonary circulation (heart-lungs-heart) is responsible for taking deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs to get oxygen, and then bringing the oxygenated blood back to the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pulmonary artery, not the pulmonary vein, carries deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs. The pulmonary vein carries the oxygenated blood from the lungs back to the heart. This is because the pulmonary circulation is responsible for taking deoxygenated blood to the lungs to get oxygen, and then bringing the oxygenated blood back to the heart.

questions.question_text: A person with blood type O can donate to anyone.
questions.explanation_correct: A person with blood type O can donate to anyone because they do not have A or B antigens on their red blood cells. This means their blood is compatible with all other blood types, making them a 'universal donor'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A person with blood type O cannot donate to anyone. This is because they do not have A or B antigens, but they do have the Rh factor. People with blood type AB can receive blood from any type, making them 'universal recipients', but they cannot donate to everyone.

questions.question_text: The heart is located slightly to the left of the center of the chest.
questions.explanation_correct: The heart is located slightly to the left of the center of the chest because the heart is not exactly in the middle of the chest. It is positioned slightly to the left, so the correct answer is true.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The heart is not located exactly in the center of the chest. It is slightly shifted to the left side. This is because the heart is a muscular organ that pumps blood throughout the body, and its position allows it to pump blood more efficiently. The incorrect answer would be that the heart is located in the exact center of the chest.

questions.question_text: Veins carry blood under high pressure.
questions.explanation_correct: Veins carry blood back to the heart under low pressure. This is because veins have thinner walls compared to arteries, which carry blood away from the heart under high pressure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Veins actually carry blood under low pressure, not high pressure. This is because veins have thin walls and are designed to transport blood back to the heart, while arteries have thick walls and carry blood away from the heart under high pressure.

questions.question_text: Plasma makes up about 55% of blood volume.
questions.explanation_correct: The statement is true. Plasma, which is the liquid part of blood, makes up about 55% of the total blood volume. The remaining 45% is composed of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Plasma, which is the liquid portion of blood, accounts for approximately 55% of the total blood volume. The rest is made up of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. Some students may think that plasma makes up a smaller percentage of blood, but this is not the case.

questions.question_text: White blood cells are also called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: White blood cells are also called leucocytes. This is the scientific name for the type of blood cells that help fight infections and keep our bodies healthy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'leucocytes'. White blood cells are a type of blood cell that play a key role in the immune system, helping to fight off infections and diseases. 'Leucocytes' is the scientific term used to refer to these important cells in the human body.

questions.question_text: The lower chambers of the heart are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The lower chambers of the heart are called ventricles. This is because the heart has four main chambers - the upper two are called atria, and the lower two are called ventricles. The ventricles pump blood out of the heart to the lungs and body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The lower chambers of the heart are not called atria, but rather ventricles. The atria are the upper chambers that receive blood flowing into the heart, while the ventricles are the lower chambers that pump blood out of the heart to the lungs and body. So the correct answer is 'ventricles'.

questions.question_text: Blood circulation between the heart and lungs is called ___ circulation.
questions.explanation_correct: The blood circulation between the heart and lungs is called pulmonary circulation because the blood passes through the lungs to pick up oxygen before returning to the heart. This is one of the two main circuits that make up the entire human circulatory system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is pulmonary circulation. This refers to the circulation of blood between the heart and the lungs, where the blood picks up oxygen. It is one of the two main circuits in the body's circulatory system, the other being the systemic circulation between the heart and the rest of the body. The term 'pulmonary' refers specifically to the lungs.

questions.question_text: The oxygen-carrying pigment in red blood cells is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The oxygen-carrying pigment in red blood cells is hemoglobin. Hemoglobin is a protein found in RBCs that can bind to oxygen, allowing the blood to transport oxygen from the lungs to the body's tissues.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'hemoglobin'. Red blood cells contain a special protein called hemoglobin that can bind to oxygen, enabling the blood to carry oxygen to all the cells in the body. The question asked specifically about the oxygen-carrying pigment, and hemoglobin is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: The natural pacemaker of the heart is the ___ node.
questions.explanation_correct: The sinoatrial (SA) node is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is located in the right atrium and generates electrical impulses that trigger the contraction of the heart muscles, causing the heart to beat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is the 'sinoatrial node'. This is the natural pacemaker of the heart, located in the right atrium. It generates the electrical signals that coordinate the contraction of the heart's chambers, causing the heart to beat. Other parts of the heart, such as the atrioventricular (AV) node, are not the primary pacemakers of the heart.

questions.question_text: The four blood groups in the ABO system are A, B, AB, and ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The fourth blood group in the ABO system is O. This is because people with type O blood do not have any A or B antigens on their red blood cells. They have neither type A nor type B blood, so they are considered the 'universal donor'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The four blood groups in the ABO system are A, B, AB, and O. The correct answer is O, as people with type O blood do not have any A or B antigens on their red blood cells. They have neither type A nor type B blood, so they are considered the 'universal donor'. The other three blood groups (A, B, and AB) have different combinations of A and B antigens on their red blood cells.

questions.question_text: The largest vein in the body that returns blood to the heart is the vena ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The largest vein in the body that returns blood to the heart is called the vena cava. This is because the vena cava is the main vein that brings deoxygenated blood from the body back to the heart, so it is the largest vein in the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'cava'. The vena cava is the largest vein in the body that returns blood to the heart. It is called the 'vena cava' because 'vena' means vein, and 'cava' refers to the large, hollow, or cavernous nature of this major vein. So the complete term 'vena cava' describes the largest vein that carries blood back to the heart.

questions.question_text: A deficiency of red blood cells or hemoglobin causes a condition called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is anemia. Anemia is a condition where there is a decrease in the number of red blood cells or the amount of hemoglobin in the blood. This can lead to symptoms like fatigue, weakness, and difficulty breathing, as the body doesn't have enough oxygen-carrying cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'anemia'. Anemia is not the same as other blood-related conditions like high blood pressure or low blood sugar. Anemia specifically refers to a lack of red blood cells or hemoglobin, which are crucial for carrying oxygen throughout the body. Without enough of these, the body can't function properly.

questions.question_text: Arrange the flow of blood through systemic circulation:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is: Left ventricle pumps blood, Aorta carries blood to body, Body cells use oxygen, Blood returns via vena cava. This is the sequence of how blood flows through the systemic circulation - the heart pumps blood out to the body, the body uses the oxygen from the blood, and the deoxygenated blood returns to the heart via the vena cava.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: Body cells use oxygen, Left ventricle pumps blood, Aorta carries blood to body, Blood returns via vena cava. This is not correct because the blood first needs to be pumped out from the heart to the body before the body cells can use the oxygen in the blood. The correct order is: Heart pumps blood, blood goes to the body, body uses the oxygen, and then the deoxygenated blood returns to the heart.

questions.question_text: Arrange chambers of the heart in the order blood flows through them:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is Right atrium, Right ventricle, Left atrium, Left ventricle because blood flows from the right atrium to the right ventricle, then to the lungs, then back to the left atrium, and finally to the left ventricle before being pumped out to the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be Left ventricle, Right atrium, Right ventricle, Left atrium. This is not correct because blood does not flow from the left ventricle to the right atrium. Instead, it flows from the right atrium to the right ventricle, then to the lungs, and back to the left atrium before going to the left ventricle.

questions.question_text: Arrange blood components by percentage in blood (highest to lowest):
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order from highest to lowest percentage in blood is: Plasma, Red blood cells, White blood cells. This is because plasma makes up the largest component of blood at around 55%, followed by red blood cells at around 45%, and white blood cells are only a small percentage at around 1%.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: White blood cells, Plasma, Red blood cells. This is wrong because white blood cells are the smallest component at around 1% of blood, while plasma makes up the largest portion at 55% and red blood cells are the second largest at around 45%. The correct order from highest to lowest percentage is Plasma, Red blood cells, White blood cells.
